Premise 1: Peter loves sex
Premise 2: Peter loves her mom
Conclusion: Therefore Peter loves sex with ...?

My current view is that premises are sometimes treacherous generalisations; P1 is, in this case, is incomplete: because Peter or anyone else would not have sex with any woman and never with members of their family. P2 is also incomplete, what love really means? Another case for instance is

P1: Humans do not have tails
P2: John Green is Human
C: John Green do not have a tail


This is an example of a valid and true argument, but it should be invalid because there are humans with tails (Google it)
So if we can agree on the danger of generalisations in premises, we need to take their conclusions with a pinch of salt; they might have a great rhetorical effect but insufficient nevertheless to prompt us to action. Deductive arguments are only of any use if you are already familiar with the subject matter or situation.

The Barber's paradox is a faulty problem setup, the problem is with point of view. When you set up this reasoning, all men who do not provide the service of shaving to themselves must have it provided for them by the designated third party. In the case of the barber you come to the paradox that he is both client and third party. This is the root of the paradox. When he shaves himself, he is not doing so as the barber, but as himself. The difference here is that self-shaving is a different action then having the shaving be provided for you, being shaved. So if the barber is the only barber, he can only self-shave. He is physically incapable of having someone else do his shaving and have that someone be himself.

You seem to be overlooking the pretty gargantuan issue of what it means to "know" something - in other words, the notion of justified true belief. You evaluate deductive arguments in a vacuum to determine whether they are valid, and then you can use that instrument to inform whether or not the conclusion can be "known." In this case, you do not know whether or not the conclusion is true from the outset, which is why I have a problem with your non sequitur there. Structurally, the argument is invalid. It just is. By definition. You are, however, giving the impression that it isn't. A valid argument has the form of:

If P, Then Q
P
Therefore Q

Whereas your example of a non-sequitur has the form:

If P, Then Q
P
Therefore Bear Riding a Hot Dog

That's why we identify that as a non-sequitur fallacy. None of your premises speak to bears, hot dogs, or using them as conveyances. That's invalid. It's not an example of a valid argument failing to work - it's a specific example of a very easily identified fallacy of argument.

A purely deductive philosophic construct would work like...well, it IS mathematics. Mathematics starts with a set of axiomatic assumptions that you conjecture and fully confess you cannot prove. In Peano Arithmetic, for instance, we start with the assumptions that A = A and A = B => B = A, and from there an entire universe of mathematics tumbles into being. The only root assumptions you have to make are those first two (and yes, I know there are more in real mathematics, but I'm just giving a rough example here). In that system, you could only possibly have an argument like your last example if your first premise happened to be axiomatic, which is why deductive systems go to great lengths to minimize the number of axiomatic premises they incorporate.

This just seems like kind of a bad way to start out on this topic. Logic is actually pretty easy to handle (and as a horrible math and computer science person I find that symbolic logic makes it trivial to understand) if you approach it from the right direction, but this...this seems to be starting off in a somewhat confused place from the offing for the sake of answering some questions from much further down the line, instead of telling the unruly student to just sit on it for a minute and we'll get there.

Objection: on 07:30 John says: "All cats are mammals, but all mammals aren't cats. Which means (thus) there are things as non-cat mammals, which I am just an example of."
What is wrong with this argument?

The mistake lies in the premise: "But all mammals aren't cats."

This premise is false because, it should have been: "Some" mammals are cats [or equally, "some" mammals are not cats]
This is different from saying that "ALL mammals are NOT cats."
By saying that "All mammals are NOT cats", we are saying that "NO cats are mammals" which is simply obviously false.

Ok, I'll give a deductive argument for the existence of a god. 1) Anything that begins to exist must have a cause. 2) The universe began to exist. 3) The universe must have a cause. Obviously, this cause would have to exist outside the universe itself since nothing within the universe would be able to bring the universe into existence in the first place. This proves a general god, but it doesn't prove any particular one. Really, the only requirement is that it is supernatural (above the natural, meaning not contained within the material universe). This argument could apply to a supernatural pink elephant as much as any traditional god (Yahweh, Allah, Zeus, etc.). So why the Judeo-Christian God, Yahweh? For that, I must turn to the religious text itself. The Bible gives many evidences for it's validity including scientific facts told long before scientists knew them, fulfilled prophecies, and archaeological/historical evidence for events recorded in Scripture. Though the most foundational event, the resurrection of Jesus Christ, is also one of the most well-documented and easily proven events in ancient history. That alone proves that Jesus Christ was a legitimate sacrifice for the penalty of the sins of mankind, it proves he was God-incarnate. Since he took Scripture as truth, it's pretty easy for me to then also accept it as such. If anyone wants me to go into specifics, I'm more than happy to.

"Man" does not solely refer to male humans. It can also refer to the human species, despite certain, incompletely informed ideologies asserting that it was spawned from some form of sexism or misogyny. Even if we completely rule out the fact that most of us here have no means of knowing that Aristotle's quote was not mistranslated or even corrupted over the centuries, there is also the fact that in Old English, obviously where modern came from at least in part, that the term for a male human had a prefix in front of 'man' just as 'woman' does, but for whatever reason was dropped.  Of course I also remember hearing plenty of anecdotal evidence that ancient Greece was objectively sexist, but whether that is true or not there is no basis now for saying that calling our species 'Man' is sexist or misogynist.

So I applaud the above video's discussion, but allow me to offer a point or two.

So, while the tripartite soul as concept served as a backdrop to this video, the truly operative ghost is Descartes. Cartesian rationalism has left fingerprints all over this video and much of anglo-american philosophy. [As an aside to an aside, many still believe in a tripartite soul, but it is just slightly different and walks as the specter of Freud. This also has left fingerprints all over the place.] Descartes and the lineage indebted and related to him are those that are most quick to uphold human rationality and argumentation as a form of battle that can be waged imperialistically, not just empirically.

There are undercurrents and strains of philosophy that both place less value on formal logic and disregard rationality. So, while I understand that philosophy is most commonly taught from the view of the establishment and the status quo that must accept the theological meta-logic of formal logic and the rationality of humans and argument as war, I don't see that is the whole story. in specific, I'm reminded of certain readings of Nietzsche, I'm thinking parts of Spinoza, I'm thinking the existentialists, I'm thinking Heidegger, thinking Camus, the phenomenologists, I'm thinking the structuralists and the post-structuralists. Even readings of Hegel can get out of this paradigm.

None of this is to take anything away from your video or the tradition that it more clearly pulls from. However, for all it lacks of clarity and formal argumentation, I don't always experience myself as a Cartesian ego, but as a Heideggerian dasein. I'm not always reflecting and rationally picking apart, I'm often doing and experiencing. Tangentially, I find myself highly sceptical of the idea that clear thinking or truth or strong argumentation makes any difference in persuading anyone and I certainly don't find humanity, mine or anyone else's, to be rational. I'm not trying to convince you, though I'd point to the experience of grief, or religious experience/belief, or yaknow, Donald Trump. This is just me flexing my legs, philosophically, having ostensibly hung this up since I graduated.

Think of this as my own exercise.

That contradiction [Russell's paradox] is extremely interesting. You can modify its form; some forms of modification are valid and some are not. I once had a form suggested to me which was not valid, namely the question whether the barber shaves himself or not. You can define the barber as "one who shaves all those, and those only, who do not shave themselves." The question is, does the barber shave himself? In this form the contradiction is not very difficult to solve. But in our previous form I think it is clear that you can only get around it by observing that the whole question whether a class is or is not a member of itself is nonsense, i.e. that no class either is or is not a member of itself, and that it is not even true to say that, because the whole form of words is just noise without meaning.

— Bertrand Russell, The Philosophy of Logical Atomism

In deduction, a very interesting argument missed here is proof by contradiction. It goes along the following lines:
1. All humans are mortal
2. Wolverine is immortal
3. Therefore Wolverine isn't human

The interesting part here is that there is a tension between this argument and the argument shown for Socrates. When we have a statement like, All X are Y and we want to use that to reason about a thing, we can go 2 ways. We can say: "the thing is X, therefore it is Y" or we can say "the thing is not Y therefore it is not X".

You see this quite often in arguments where two people agree on the All X are Y part, but one party wants to argue the thing is X or Y, whilst the other wants to argue the thing isn't. This is also where this kind of reasoning is vulnerable because the premises must really always be true in every circumstance. Sadly this is very rarely the case and even more rarely verify-ably so.

Consider the argument for Socrates. How do we really know that all humans are mortal. There certainly exist humans that have yet to die. Things get even dicier when you state Socrates is human. What does it even mean to be human. Where 'Neanderthals 'human'?

In short, deduction is really nice, and it is important that your arguments are valid, but real discussion tends to be about whether or not your premises are true.

Crashcourse.... you are essentially correct in saying that if the Premises are true, then the conclusion must be true, but a little more care needs to be taken when talking about deductive arguments.   Deductive arguments are variously declared as being:   Valid,  Valid and Sound, Valid but Unsound or Invalid.     The conclusion of a Sound, Valid Deductive argument may be accepted as ''true''.   The classic syllogism:  'Premise 1:  All humans are mortal.   Premise 2:  Socrates is a human.  Conclusion:  Socrates is mortal'  is a convenient example.   Someone might want to dispute either of the Premises, but if the premises are known or shown to be true, then the conclusion follows with necessity - rendering it also ''true''.

"If you are human, then you are mortal."
"You are human."

Philosophy is my one true love, and I'm really enjoying this series so far! I'm really happy you emphasized that validity doesn't equal truth. Logic is a tender topic for me, especially since I'm more continental in my philosophy.

I just want to emphasize a bit more myself for whoever might be reading. Logic itself has nothing to do with truth, nor content. I can literally construct an argument like:
All flingflops are gobbles
Gallyhoops are flingflops
Therefore Gallyhoops are gobbles

This argument is logically sound and follow all the rules, but it's nonsensical. Now on the flip side, I see a lot of people in arguments referring to scientific material and theory in discussions where it actually doesn't apply, but still sorta fits. Like, the scientific materials don't add value to their argument, or anything like that. As in, the premise of the science doesn't support their conclusions (even though they might be on the same topic/theme). And then they say "Follow reason! Follow logic!" Doesn't work like that.

Although science is founded on strong logical systems (Seriously read some of the philosophers on science, it is a ride! REALLY interesting and has a lot to do with how we ended up with our scientific process and why we decided on this one), it still doesn't mean it supports every argument.

Logic and reasoning definitely helps in argumentation, but there is still more than that. At the core it's also the creative process of being able to apply values to premises and construct them to conclusions. Logic don't teach you that. That's another skill that's super hard to refine.

I hope in the future you also dive in more continental philosophy too!

Idiotic opening statement about sexism.

It is now hard for people to quote Aristotle's famous dictum, "Man is a rational animal," without gratuitously adding that this is a "sexist" remark because, presumably, Aristotle didn't say "human beings" [...] Even if we think that English "man" is "sexist," Aristotle was, of course, not speaking English. And in contrast with English, Greek and Latin both "mark" the male as well as the female in their vocabulary: anér in Greek and vir in Latin both mean "man=male"; gyné in Greek and femina in Latin both mean "woman"; and ánthrôpos in Greek and homo in Latin both mean "man=person." Aristotle said "ánthrôpos," not "anér; and Classics scholars are usually happy to point out the inclusiveness of the former term. Curiously, Old English made distinctions like Greek and Latin. "Man=male" was wer (cognate of Latin vir and Irish fear, preserved in "werewolf"), while "woman" was wif (preserved as "wife" and in "fishwife" and "midwife" -- "woman" itself is from wifman). Old English man was "one," "someone," or "man=person" [...] However, ánthrôpos, homo, and man are all in the masculine gender. Since Greek and Latin are languages where every noun has gender, like French, Hebrew, etc., there is actually no grammatically "gender neutral" expression possible, as there is in Modern English. So was Aristotle sexist after all? If so, then we are still using a sexist expression in "human beings" because "human" is from homo, which had masculine gender to start with.

A fairly good episode, but I feel like it tried to take too large a bite out of ancient philosophy and ended up trying to talk with its mouth full.

Covering the 3 kinds of appeals (ethos, logos, and pathos) is a great start to a discussion on philosophy. I would have perhaps presented it a little differently. Ethos doesn't appeal to emotion, it appeals to meaning and purpose (or teleology in the Greek). Pathos appeals to emotions, which for Aristotle, would have been the base desires.

The deduction section felt a tad rushed, but that's understandable. The word "syllogism" should have popped up at least once, though. The "moving from a universal to a particular" was a strange and not entirely accurate way to describe deduction (unless you're limited to arguments about ontologies). That could lead to confusion in the future, especially if you want to sink your teeth deeper into logic (such as explaining the interesting differences between ancient and modern logic).

I think I would have started with an episode on Plato and Socrates before Aristotle, but I understand there may not be enough episodes for that. It's just hard to jump straight to Aristotle without Plato considering that one is just an advancement of the other (don't be fooled by their apparent differences). If you want to "sell" philosophy to people, understanding how it was born from Socratic thought and why it was put to death is a great springboard. It's a story that has inspired people to take up the mantle of philosopher for almost 2500 years now.

I'm interested to see how induction is handled in the next episode, especially considering that this is usually a series (when it's hosted by Hank) that is deeply in love with the sciences. Induction is really faulty, and the fact that our most effective means of knowing about the world is entirely dependent on it isn't a very popular notion amongst people who haven't really studied those issues. Will it be glossed over? I'm curious to see. Even if it is taken uncritically, there's still a great opportunity to cast serious doubts about empiricism with Hume.

Anachronism aside, there's no need to correct Aristotle's use of the term 'man' in 'man is a rational animal.'

The phrase itself is only a paraphrase from a passage in the Nicomachean Ethics 1098a (although similar terms are used in the Politics), which isn't discussing 'man' in our modern, gendered sense (which would be ἀνήρ in Greek) but 'human being' (ἄνθρωπος 'anthropos'). A better rendering of the popular paraphrase would be, 'A human being is a rational animal.'

As near as I can tell, we find the term 'man' used in English for a couple of reasons. First, most public domain translations are older and use 'man' as an unmarked noun (not intending to indicate gender). These days, however, we tend to use it as a gendered term. Second, when the phrase is translated from languages like Latin, sometimes the gendered term is conventionally used. This is the case with the medieval 'homo est animal rationale'. I haven't checked, but I would guess Heidegger uses 'Mann' rather than 'Mensch' in the German, which would produce a similar effect.

In short, Aristotle doesn't speak of males as rational animals. He applies this definition to all human beings.

This video spreads a few misconceptions about deductive reasoning.

First, there's nothing in the nature of a deductively valid argument that requires the argument go from more general premises to a more particular conclusion. For instance, consider this argument:

1 I have thumbs
2 If I have thumbs, then I have hands.
3 Therefore, I have hands

This argument is deductively valid, but premise one is no more general than the conclusion.

Second, towards the end of the video, Hank implies that deductive reasoning requires certain premises. He then argues that deduction can only give you "deductive truths" which are "hard to come by", and that if you have less than certainty, you'll need another form of argument. However, the validity of an argument has nothing to do with your credence in the premises. Now, in order for an argument to be (justifiably) convincing, your justification in the premises must be greater than your justification for the negation of the conclusion, but this is a far cry from thinking deduction delivers only certain truths. For instance, consider this argument:

4 There is evil in the world
5 If there is evil in the world, then there is no God
6 Therefore, there is no God

Whether we are more justified in this argument's premises than we are in the negation of the conclusion is pretty contentious among philosophers. But even many of those who would advocate the above argument would admit they have less than certainty in the premises above. Nevertheless, they would say that we learned something of value from the argument, since though we are not certain of the premises' truth, we are more justified in accepting the premises than in denying the conclusion.

Furthermore, even if you are not convinced by the argument above, the argument in question should be of philosophical interest to you, since denying the above argument commits you the the falsity of at least one of the premises, which might have been surprising to you before you encountered the argument, and which might have interesting philosophical consequences.

However, there are informal fallacies, such as destruction of the exception. Unlike the mammals and cats argument, in which something can be a mammal but not be a cat, there are such things as an example hosted on wikipedia:
1) Surgeons cut people.
2) Cutting people is a crime.
3) Therefore, surgeons are criminals.
While there is no grouping error, as with cats and mammals, and it is technically true by strict definition of deductive reasoning, it ignores an obvious exception to something which is generally true (thus, "destruction of the exception").

In other words, deductive reasoning can not truly be said to determine if something is absolutely true, even if handled correctly, without including other elements of logic. That is, it's 'truth' only exists implicitly, rather than explicitly (a point you made somewhat passively at 8:40).

The deductive reasoning reminded me of the proofs I did in Geometry. You could prove you answer was right based on the steps you wrote down but that doesn't mean the teacher wasn't going to mark it wrong when the answer was incorrect, despite your confusion with how you put the information together.

If it helps anybody: if you want to check if your argument is valid, take your conclusion and hypothesise that it's false. Now, if your argument is valid, you should find that your hypothesised false conclusion will contradict something in your premises. If your hypothesised false conclusion doesn't contradict anything in your premises, your argument is sadly invalid.

So, for example:

1. Donald Trump says he will make America great again.
2. America needs somebody with can-do spirit.
---
3. Therefore, Donald Trump will be a good president.

Let's hypothesise that our conclusion is false. So: Donald Trump will not be a good president. Does this contradict either (1) or (2) above? No, it clearly doesn't. Therefore, we have an invalid argument on our hands.

GUYS: I am pretty sure the sexism thing was just a joke, but, if you care...

"Man" in its original Old English meaning meant "human", the term for "male human" being "werman", wer meaning "warrior". That is the original of the term "werewolf": this is a wolf that is akin to a male human, and a very violent one at that. "Woman" originated from "wifman", that is "wife-man". However, over time, because of phonetic changes, "wifman" and "werman" became very similar, so in order to avoid confusion, the Englishmen started saying "man" to mean "male human".

So it was not Aristotle that was sexist (at least, any more sexist than all Athenians - they were basically the Saudi Arabians of their age), nor were his English translators, because that was the meaning of the word at the time. Now however the correct translation would be "human", as "man" nowadays only means "male human" most of the time.

Neither were Anglo-Saxons sexist when they called women "wife-men": actually, like most Germanic people and most warrior cultures (Spartans and Mongols say hello) they held women in very high regard, as they had to maintain the economy when men were off warring, and women had a lot of rights in their society. (Yes, WOMEN HAD RIGHTS. I bet you're crying now - both feminists and conservative MRAs)


"Wife" in that case does not imply submission. Also, in many languages, such as Ukrainian, "wife" and "woman" are one word, as are "man" and "husband".
